description: Borrowed from Late Latin praeceptum, form of praecipiō (“to teach”), from Latin prae (“pre-”) + capiō (“take”).

entries.meaning: A rule or principle, especially one governing personal conduct.
(law) A written command, especially a demand for payment.

definitionGroups.group: (UK)  An order issued by one local authority to another specifying the rate of tax to be charged on its behalf.

entries.meaning: A rate or tax set by a precept.

verbs.description: precept (third-person singular simple present precepts, present participle precepting, simple past and past participle precepted)

entries.meaning: (intransitive, chiefly US, medicine) To act as a preceptor; to teach a physician-in-training by supervising their clinical practice.
